This has improved Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a living document. It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.

1.3.2 Chlorine

The chlorination process at the Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates for only a few months out of the year. The chlorination process utilizes eight (8) 1-ton containers (16,000 lbs) and ten (10) 150 lb cylinders (1,500 lbs). As with the ammonia process management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of a chlorine leak. 

Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District personnel monitor the chlorination process. In addition, the process is checked frequently during the operational season by our outside water treatment contractor. This contractor also assists in performing the annual mechanical integrity review of our chlorine equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
- California Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR §3220
- Federal Emergency Action Plan - Title 29 CFR §1910.38 

Strategically, we will respond minimally to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all nece

lorine is injected through three Wallace and Tiernan V-notch chlorinators to a sump of water located beneath the chlorine room. 

A partial list of system components includes: 
(8) Ton containers (maximum) 
(10) Cylinders (maximum)
(3) Chlorinators

Process Chemistry

At Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District chlorine gas (Cl2) is used for disinfection of water distributed to residential and irrigation customers. The chlorine, when added to water, yields both hydrochloric (HCl) and hypochlorous (HOCl) acid (see chemical equation below) in aqueous solution. This combination is effective in killing bacteria, viruses, pathogens and other micro-organisms. Note that the equation below is easily reversible which results in “off-gassing” of chlorine gas from water that contains high concentrations of the acids.

Cl2 + H2O → HOCl + HCl

The chlorination process begins with the chlorine gas being drawn from the ton container through a pressure reducing valve, reduced to vacuum at a vacuum regulator valve mounted inside the chlorinator, metered through a manually-adjusted rate valve, and finally injected into water.

Process Classification

The chlorine system at Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District consists of ton containers and cylinders which are co-located relative to each other. As such, the chlorine system at Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District is treated as a single process.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of chlorine in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the chlorine process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The resu

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Description

Facility Overview

Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District owns and operates the Trauger Pumping Plant in Lindsay, CA. The facility uses chlorine to disinfect water that is served to land and residences within the District.

Facility Location

Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District is located at 23260 Round Valley Dr, Lindsay, CA 93247. The latitude and longitude of the chlorine room is 36.203406, -119.055032. The facility is located approximately 2.75 miles east of state highway 65 in a rural area surrounded primarily by agriculture land.

According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in “an area of minimal flood hazard”.
Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation.Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed the following faults within close proximity:
Pond Fault - <150 Years
Unnamed Fault in California - <1,600,000 Years
Unnamed Faults Near Rag Gulch - <1,600,000 Years
Poso Creek Fault - <1,600,000 Years 

The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District has a 1-2% chance of experiencing “potentially minor-damage” due to ground shaking in 2018.

1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name                | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)
Chlorine Process              Chlorine                                   17,500

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have:
